text: (soft music)
- Hi, I'm Andy Jassy.
I'm the CEO of Amazon,

and I am so excited to
be here at re:Invent.

This is my first time I've
been back to re:Invent

in the three years I've
been doing my current job.

I just got into Vegas
and so we're gonna try
and experiment this week.
I don't know how it's gonna work out.
Maybe you'll tell me how it works out,

but we're gonna try a
few times during the week

to video some things, I'm
gonna try during the week

as we have days chockfull
of launches to maybe share
with you the launches that I think
are most excited about or most impactful.

And we're just gonna periodically
do it during the week,

but I'm gonna start today
with just having gotten
to re:Invent here in Las Vegas
and maybe just reminisce a little bit.
So we started working on AWS
in the fall of 2003.
And the vision and the mission that we had

was to enable any
individual in their garage

or their dorm room to have
access to the same cost structure
and scale of infrastructure technology

that people had at the largest
companies in the world.

Back then, when we were
thinking about this in 2003,
we used PeopleSoft as our example.
So the world changes pretty quickly

and you know, we had
this internal need inside
of Amazon to be able

to build our applications
much faster without each team

having to reinvent the
wheel on compute and storage

and database and content
distribution analytics.
And so we figured if we had that need

as a pretty strong
technical company at Amazon,
it was probably likely that a lot
of other companies had that same need.

What ended up happening is
we started building AWS was,
we eventually hired a marketing team
and we hired people

who had worked at other
enterprise technology companies.
And almost every year it became a ritual

that the marketing team
would propose to me
that we should do our own conference.

And for three or four years
in a row, I would read

the presentation, which
was always a narrative.

That's how we do all our
communication information.

And I would look at it
and I would say, nope,
I don't think we should do a conference.

And the team would get
very frustrated with me

and I actually kind of
wanted to do a conference,
but we hadn't done it before.
We didn't have enough people to be able

to do a conference well in
the fourth quarter of the year
and still get all the deliveries we
needed to get to all of you.
And every proposal that we saw was

for the typical corporate
technology conference,
which none of us wanted to do.

And so it wasn't really
until maybe the fourth
or fifth try that we had somebody propose
what ended up becoming re:Invent

and the way that they were
able to compel us to do it,

in part, we had enough
people where we thought
we could do something good for all of you

and still deliver what I know
is most important to you,
which are the features and services
that you build great applications quickly
and cost effectively.
But really what it was also was
that the team had lots of ideas

to make this a conference
that was a learning conference
and it was a little bit quirky,

not like your typical enterprise
technology conference.

So when you come to
re:Invent, the theme should be

that you come to learn, you
learn from the keynotes,
you learn from the breakout sessions,
you learn from each other.
And hopefully what it does

is it helps you understand
a little bit more

about what's happening in the
cloud, a little bit more about

what you can use to build
great customer experiences.
And if you come as a team,

or even if you come as the
representative for your company,
that you get inspired by what's available,

what's been released, and
what all your peers are doing
'cause you can really feel the energy

and the vibe here to
go back to your company
and figure out how to change

what your customer experiences
are and your businesses are.

And that's what re:Invent
historically has been.

Now, I also remember a
lot of the early debates
in what we were doing with re:Invent.
First of all, it took us probably
a ridiculously embarrassing amount of time
to name re:Invent.

We had all sorts of other
names until we came up

with re:Invent, which
today seems so natural,
but I can tell you it took us four months

and probably six or seven
meetings to figure out
that we wanted to call it re:Invent.
But we've always had fun quirky events
that round out re:Invent.

You know, we have a buffalo
wing eating contest,
we've had broom ball competitions.
We've done weddings here over the years

with a chapel, you can still
get tattoos and piercings.

One of my good friends got
an AWS re:Invent tattoo.

I reminded him, you know,
like tattoos are permanent.
They're not easily removed.

You can take it off, but
they're not easily removed.
But it has always felt like a
gathering of a community.
And that's what I'm hopeful
that you're gonna find this coming week.
And so we have a lot of learning for you,

a lot of sessions for you,
a lot of really interesting
and intelligent and inventive people
that you'll get to interact with.
But we also have a lot of releases
and new goodies that we're gonna share
with you over the coming days.
I hope to come back
and share with you some of the ones

that I think are most
exciting, most impactful.
But I hope to see you during the week
and I hope we have a great week together.
Thank you.
(soft music)
